abstract: Investigation by ProPublica and New York Times finds New Jersey's student loan repayment program Higher Education Student Assistance Authority is more stringent than those elsewhere in country, with limitations that can easily lead to financial ruin; harshness of program is illustrated by hardship faced by Marcia DeOliveira-Longinetti, who was told she had to pay her son's loans after his death.

headline.print_headline: Even Death Is No Reprieve From a Student’s Debt
headline.main: In New Jersey Student Loan Program, Even Death May Not Bring a Reprieve

snippet: Called “state-sanctioned loan-sharking” by a bankruptcy lawyer, the program’s aggressive collections and stringent rules can easily mean financial ruin for borrowers....
lead_paragraph: Called “state-sanctioned loan-sharking” by a bankruptcy lawyer, the program’s aggressive collections and stringent rules can easily mean financial ruin for borrowers.
